Award.AwardTitle: Deltaic Resilience and the Genesis of Mesopotamian Cities (Iraq)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support Drs. Jennifer Pournelle, Carrie Hritz and Jennifer Smith will undertake a three year program of archaeological, geoarchaeological and geomorphological research in southern Iraq. The focus is on wetland regions which the investigators believe may have played a major role in the rise of Mesopotamian civilization. These marshlands were originally difficult to survey but draining in recent years has provided a unique opportunity - a window which likely will soon be closed - as the region is restored to its prior state.

The Tigris-Euphrates delta of southern Iraq has been the locus of a continuous urban presence for over five millennia. The height of early Sumerian civilization there at the onset of the 4th millennium BC marked a degree of economic differentiation, socio-political complexity and urbanization theretofore unseen anywhere in the world. While the Sumerians made use of irrigable plains and pasture lands in the surrounding regions, it is also postulated that the society drew significant wealth and transportation advantage from their situation in a deltaic system that provided varied and abundant resources even through cycles of dramatic climatic fluctuation. The investigators believe that this "deltaic resiliency" sustained the urbanizing processes through multiple systemic changes involving both social and environmental change. Compared with adjacent environments relatively little is known about this deltaic component and the investigators will collect relevant archaeological, geological and paleoenvironmental data. They will both reconstruct past environmental patterns and examine human responses within this context.

One important practical result of this project will be the strengthening of archaeological ties between the US and Iraq and the opportunity this research may provide for future archaeological projects in the country. The results of the work may also guide projects to restore environmental resources to Iraq's southern cities, promote resilient environmental management strategies, and support sustainable lifeways for the future. Both American and Iraqi students will be involved in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
After a dozen field seasons combatting sweltering heat, blinding dust, choking oil fumes, flash floods, economic crises, governmental shutdowns, bureacratic shuffling, and gruelling treks across impassable mudflats and along miles-long canals carpeted with fish kills, we finished the job. We trucked and boated and just plain walked hundreds of miles, collected dozens of cores and soil samples, ran scores of radiocarbon dates, photographed hundreds of potsherd, picked thousands of tiny fossils out of packed, grey clay, and subjected pounds of dirt to, well, every test we could think of. 

The result? The world's oldest known, longest occupied cities weren't born, and did not thrive, in a desert. They grew in or alongside marshes in the Tigris-Euphrates delta. And as the delta grew, or shrank; came, or went - so did they. In an area the geographic size of South Carolina's Low Country, for over 6,000 years, there were always two: an entrepot, where people from all directions could meet and trade and stockpile resources fro the rich lands around them, and a downstream port, where those goods could be traded onward by sea. As the delta moved southeastward, the entrepot would  be slowly left high and dry, forced to expend ever-more labor on irrigation and cultivation, until the water failed altogether. Meanwhile, the port grew - until it became the new entrepot, and founded its new port downstream. 

That process started with Uruk and Ur, in what became ancient Sumer. Today, it is represented by Basra and Fao, in modern Basra Governorate. Until 2001, Basra (and other cities of southern Iraq), and the cities that preceded it  enjoyed all the benefits provided by vast, healthy marshes: clean(ed) water, fishing grounds, duck hunting, fuel, construction material, fodder for all manner of livestock, and easy transport and trade routes along reed-lined waterways. 

Deprived of this resource, Basra now shows all the signs of strain that affected its predecessors for six millenia: ever-increasing reliance on food imports and irrigated crops, a collapse of its livestock industires; water-borne disease, and an infux of millions of displaced peoples who scrape by on slaish wages. We conclude: Unless Basra can re-introduce the critical, but (until they are gone) invisible, ecosystem services that sustained its sister trade cities for those six millenia, it too will go the way of Uruk - a mile-wide, dusty bowl, littered with ancient rubbish and debris, inhabited by ghosts.

But, we now argue, this need not be. Armed with the results of this project, we next aim to construct new wetlands, specially designed to clean wastewater from Iraq's cities, farms, and industries -- and as it does that, to cool the air, feed the livestock, support the fisheries, and provide homes and livelihoods as they have since Iraq's earliest kings tallied reed stockpiles in antiquity.
